intro.p: Consider the vector field \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{F1}}, and the surface S: the portion of the {{surface1}} {{surface1eqn}}={{k}} where {{cutv}}\leq {{cutoff}}, oriented outwards.

content.p: Parameterize \partial S, the boundary of S.

outtro.p: \partial S=C, where C is parameterized by \mathbf{r}(t)={{R1}}, {{tmin1}} \leq t \leq {{tmax1}}.

content.p: Use Stokes theorem to find an integral which computes the flux of the curl of \mathbf{F} through S.

intro.p: Consider the vector field \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{F2}}, and the closed contour C: traversing points {{#V}} {{.}}, {{/V}} then back to the beginning, oriented in a counter-clockwise orientation

content.p: Describe and parameterize the surface S bounded by C.

outtro.p: S is a {{surface2}} parameterized by \mathbf{X}(s,t)={{rst}}, {{smin}}\leq s \leq {{smax}}, {{tmin}}\leq t\leq {{tmax}}.

content.p: Use Stokes theorem to find an integral which computes the circulation of \mathbf{F} across C.

outtro.p: Note that the normal vector is given by \mathbf{T}_s\times\mathbf{T}_t = {{normvec}}. We see that the curl of \mathbf{F} is \nabla\times \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{curlF2}}, and when restricted to S may be parameterized as \nabla\times \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}(s, t))={{curlF2flat}}.

\displaystyle \oint_C \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{s} = \iint_{S} \nabla\times \mathbf{F}\cdot d\mathbf{S} = \iint_{S} (\nabla\times \mathbf{F}(\mathbf{X}(s, t)))\cdot (\mathbf{T}_s\times\mathbf{T}_t) dsdt \displaystyle = \int_{ s = {{smin}} }^{ s = {{smax}} } \int_{ t = {{tmin}} }^{ t = {{tmax}} } {{integrand2}}\ dt\ ds={{integ2}}.
